results.title: Prince Philip in the Gambia
results.brief_description: An account of the visit during the 1956-57 world tour photographed by members of the Royal Naval School of Photography. Highlights include the official welcome, a gathering of chiefs and a crocodile shoot.

results.title: Prince Philip
results.brief_description: A biographical film of H.R.H. The Duke of Edinburgh. A Prince of the Greek Royal House, H.R.H. was virtually adopted by the family of his British uncle, Lord Louis Mountbatten. It was at the Royal Naval College at Dartmouth during a Royal visit that he had an early meeting with Princess Elizabeth. The film includes footage of H.R.H. visitng Paris and Washington, tours of South Africa and Canada and closes dramatically with his declaration of allegiance to the Queen at her Coronation. Narrated by Jack Hawkins and John Arlott.

results.title: Prince of palms
results.creator_credit: Malayan Film Unit and A Peter Amavasi
results.brief_description: An account of Malaya’s third largest industry. The coconut palm is grown as a crop mainly for the extraction of oil from its nut, but it is put to a variety of other uses, ranging from rope-making from its fibre to the carving of ornamental containers from the shell.

results.title: Primeval survivors
results.creator_credit: Hugh Macdonald, New Zealand National Film Unit and Greg Stitt
results.brief_description: The Tuatura is the sole survivor of a reptile species that is now confined to a few off-shore islands in New Zealand. The film is set on tiny Stevens Island, a wildlife sanctuary which is home for 100,000 of these unique reptiles.

results.title: Prime time
results.brief_description: Shows how to distinguish between prime and composite numbers by presenting a story in which a specialist in space communications helps maintain contact with intelligent life on a newly discovered planet.

results.title: Prime suspect
results.creator_credit: Don Leaver, Granada Television International and Christopher Menaul
results.brief_description: The first episode of the award winning series written by Lynda La Plante. In the early hours of a winter morning the body of a brutally murdered young woman is discovered in a small bedsit. DCI Shefford is put in charge of the investigation, however the situation quickly changes when he suffers a massive heart attack and is replaced by the ambitious Jane Tennison (Helen Mirren). DCI Tennison soon discovers the difficulties of heading a homicide enquiry. Not only do her male colleagues resent the fact that she is a woman and do all they can to obstruct her, but the case itself is particularly difficult when it comes to charging the suspect George Marlow (John Bowe). Although Tennison and her team are convinced of the killer, they are unable to prove it until a second body is found and what started as a single murder develops into an investigation stretching back over ten years and implicating police officials. Cast includes Tom Bell, Zoe Wanamaker, John Benfield, Brian Pringle, Tom Wilkinson and a brief appearance by Ralph Fiennes.

results.title: Primary sources: the raw material of history
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Introduction to History”.
The film uses London as a place to show how different primary sources can be used to study its history. The primary sources include an excavated Roman bath-house, early documents, pottery, maps, paintings, business records and archival film.

results.title: Pride and principle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
An extract from the feature film “Bridge on the River Kwai” in which Sir Alec Guiness as the Commanding Officer refuses to give in to the Japanese over the issue of not allowing his officers to work. Raises issues surrounding pride and its consequences. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Pride and prejudice. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Powell, BBC, ABC-TV (Australia) and Cyril Coke
results.brief_description: Fay Weldon’s screenplay is outstanding in this production of the much loved Jane Austen novel. Elizabeth Bennett takes an immediate dislike to the haughty but wealthy and handsome Mr. Darcy. Her prejudice blinds her to his true character, while his pride and belief in his own superiority, alienates him from most of society. Their path to love and happiness leads them to not only discovering each other, but to a better understanding of their own natures, faults and strengths. Stars Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul as Elizabeth and Darcy.

results.title: Pride - the saddle horse. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description: Junior social studies film showing various rules of the horse in modern life and tracing the developments and training of a colt until he becomes a prize saddle horse at three years of age. Depicts stages of colt’s growth, early life with mother, first shoeing, training for stance, breaking to the saddle, learning the gaits, and performing at a horse show.
